Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: The taxi driver ensures the cab remains neat and hygienic.
Story: I stared at my phone, my sister’s message lighting up the screen: “Don’t forget, you promised to help set up for the family dinner tonight. Mom’s counting on you.” I could almost hear her voice, a mix of excitement and expectation. Family gatherings were sacred in our house, and missing one was unthinkable. But as I glanced at the backseat of my cab, I noticed a coffee stain on the upholstery and crumbs scattered from my last passenger. My next fare was a regular who always complimented my spotless car. I prided myself on my professionalism—clean cab, friendly service, always on time. The clock ticked closer to the dinner hour, and I felt the pressure mounting. If I rushed home to help, I’d have to leave the mess for later, risking my reputation. If I stayed to clean, I’d be late for the family, letting them down. My hands trembled on the steering wheel, torn between the warmth of my family’s expectations and the pride I took in my work. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, and I sat there, paralyzed, unsure which part of myself to disappoint.
